{{for|'''Kurosagi - Corpse Delivery Service'''|The Kurosagi Corpse Delivery Service}} {{Infobox animanga/Header | name = The Black Swindler | image = Kurosagi-Volume1.jpg | caption = Volume 1 Cover | ja_kanji = クロサギ | ja_romaji = Kurosagi | genre = }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = Takeshi Natsuhara | illustrator = Kuromaru | publisher = [[Shogakukan]] | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | magazine = [[Weekly Young Sunday]]
[[Big Comic Spirits]] | first = November 2003 | last = July 2008 | volumes = 20 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Shin Kurosagi | author = Takeshi Natsuhara | illustrator = Kuromaru | publisher = [[Shogakukan]] | publisher_en = | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | imprint = | magazine = [[Big Comic Spirits]] | magazine_en = | first = September 2008 | last = March 2013 | volumes = 18 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | title = Shin Kurosagi Kanketsu-hen | author = Takeshi Natsuhara | illustrator = Kuromaru | publisher = [[Shogakukan]] | publisher_en = | demographic = ''[[Seinen manga|Seinen]]'' | imprint = | magazine = [[Big Comic Spirits]] | magazine_en = | first = August 27, 2012 | last = July 29, 2013 | volumes = 4 | volume_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = drama | director = Yasuharu Ishii
Shunichi Hirano
Atsushi Takei | producer = | writer = Takeshi Natsuhara | music = | studio = | network = [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] | first = April 14, 2006 | last = June 23, 2006 | episodes = 11 | episode_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''Kurosagi'''''|クロサギ|lit.|''The Black Swindler''}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[manga]] written by Takeshi Natsuhara and illustrated by Kuromaru. The series is about a boy named Kurosaki who swindles only other professional swindlers known as {{nihongo|''shirosagi''|シロサギ}}. It won the 2008 [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for [[seinen]]/general manga along with Tetsuji Sekiya's ''[[Bambino!]]''.{{cite web|url=http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |script-title=ja:小学館漫画賞：歴代受賞者 |publisher=Shogakukan |language=Japanese |accessdate=2008-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929094941/http://comics.shogakukan.co.jp/mangasho/rist.html |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} The series was adapted as an 11-episode TV drama that was aired on [[Tokyo Broadcasting System|TBS]] from 14 April 2006 to 23 June 2006. On March 8, 2008, ''[[Kurosagi (film)|Kurosagi]]'' with [[Tomohisa Yamashita]] starring as the Black Swindler once again, was released. ==Plot== Six years ago, Kurosaki's family was destroyed when a "shirosagi" (a "white swindler", who focuses on defrauding others) swindled Kurosaki's father of their family's life savings. As a result, his father killed Kurosaki's mother and sister before committing suicide. Since then, Kurosaki has devoted himself to becoming a "kurosagi" ("black swindler"), who swindles other swindlers, as a means of revenge. As a "kurosagi," Kurosaki's acts have helped innocent victims of swindling schemes get their money back. However, he is frequently met with opposition by a stubborn grad student, who seeks to become a prosecutor. ==Characters== * {{nihongo|'''Kurosaki'''|黒崎}} : A 21-year-old famed swindler known as the Kurosagi (or Black Swindler) because he only targets professional swindlers, conning them out of their own money, leaving them in ruins, and then using that money to pay back their victims. * {{nihongo|'''Tsurara Yoshikawa'''|吉川氷柱|''Yoshikawa Tsurara''}} : Tsurara Yoshikawa is a law student who disapproves of Kurosagi's swindling ways but falls in love with him. She lives in Kurosaki's apartment as a tenant. Her dream is to be a prosecutor. When she accidentally discovers Kurosaki's job as a "kurosagi", he kicks her out of the apartment in order to protect her from the repercussions of his actions rather than facing the other option of silencing her. * {{nihongo|'''Toshio Katsuragi'''|桂木敏夫|''Katsuragi Toshio''}} : Known as the "Fixer", Katsuragi is an information broker who supplies Kurosaki with information for a cut of the profit Kurosaki makes and supports Kurosaki with acts such as buying defunct companies and being the mastermind behind many of Kurosaki's schemes. Though he is somewhat of a father-figure to Kurosaki, he is a nefarious character as he employs other swindlers aside from Kurosaki. He uses his snack bar as his formal base. * {{nihongo|'''Masaru Kashina'''|神志名将|''Kashina Masaru''}} : Appearing in the film adaptation of the series, Masaru Kashina is the newly appointed assistant inspector of the East Tokyo Department, in charge of intellectual crimes. Self-righteous and dedicated to returning law and order to Tokyo, he becomes obsessed with apprehending Kurosaki after learning of the Black Swindler and his methods of operation. Because his paternal uncle was a swindler, Kashina was adopted by his mother's relatives and had faked his death when he was two years old in order to create a new identity in order to pursue the swindlers he despises. == Cast == * [[Tomohisa Yamashita]] as Kurosaki (Kurosagi) * [[Maki Horikita]] as Tsurara Yoshikawa * [[Yui Ichikawa]] as Yukari Mishima * Koji Kato as Yoichi Shiraishi * [[Tsutomu Yamazaki]] as Toshio Katsuragi * [[Shiro Kishibe]] as Mikimoto * Ryosei Tayama]] as Tetsuji Momoyama * Reina as Yuuko Osawa * Kaoru Okunuki as Hayasa * [[Tetta Sugimoto]] as Kurosaki's Father * [[Show Aikawa]] as Masaru Kashina ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://spi-net.jp/rensai_sakuhin/kurosagi/index.html Official Website of Manga] {{ja icon}} * [http://www.tbs.co.jp/kuro-sagi/ Official Website of Drama] {{ja icon}} * [http://kurosagi-movie.jp/ Official Website of Movie] {{ja icon}} * {{ann|manga|6239|Kurosagi}} {{TBS Kin'yō Dorama}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - General}} [[Category:2003 manga]] [[Category:Business in anime and manga]] [[Category:Japanese television dramas based on manga]] [[Category:Fraud in fiction]] [[Category:Kin'yō Dorama]] [[Category:Screenplays by Eriko Shinozaki]] [[Category:Seinen manga]] [[Category:Shogakukan manga]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for general manga]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}}
The '''Malaysia International Islamic Financial Centre''' ('''MIFC''') is an initiative of [[Malaysia|Malaysia’s]] financial market regulators and relevant government agencies dedicated to developing Malaysia’s [[Islamic banking and finance|Islamic finance]] market by engaging with industry and government.<ref>Law Kai Chow (12 August 2008). "Malaysia to strengthen position as Islamic financial hub". The Star. Retrieved 4 February 2013</ref> The initiative was launched in 2006<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sc.com.my/wp-content/uploads/eng/html/resources/annual/ar2006_eng/pdf/part3.pdf|format=PDF|title=Part Three : Strengthen market competitiveness|website=Sc.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> and is based in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.
The MIFC is supported by [[Bank Negara Malaysia]], [[Securities Commission Malaysia]], Labuan Financial Services Authority, and [[Bursa Malaysia]]. The MIFC’s private sector partners include Islamic banks, conventional banks with Islamic banking windows, investment banks, brokers, lawyers, Shariah advisory firms, Shariah scholars, accounting and tax advisers, ratings agencies and takaful providers.<ref>"Nazir Hails Initiative To Set Up MIFC". Bernama. 14 August 2006. Retrieved 4 February 2013</ref>
==Malaysia World's Islamic Finance Marketplace== Islamic finance in Malaysia has developed into a comprehensive and sophisticated Islamic finance marketplace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnm.gov.my/index.php?ch=en_press&pg=en_press_all&ac=2855|title=- Bank Negara Malaysia - Central Bank of Malaysia|author=|date=|website=Bnm.gov.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> The marketplace is characterised by a robust regulatory, supervisory, Shariah and legal framework, a deep primary market and active secondary sukuk market, a diverse players and talent<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_contents_directory|title=Directory|author=|date=|website=Mifc.com|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> base with global capabilities and connectivity for business deals anywhere in the world, product innovation, breadth and depth and an efficient system for multi-currency clearing and settlement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businessislamica.com/home/ArticleDetail/62 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121153847/http://www.businessislamica.com/home/ArticleDetail/62 |archivedate=21 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Malaysia’s Islamic finance marketplace is open to global industry players and market participants to collaborate with and mutually benefit from a highly conducive business environment of innovation,<ref>[http://etp.pemandu.gov.my/Invest_In_Malaysia-@-Why_Malaysia%5E.aspx] {{dead link|date=July 2018}}</ref> expertise and deal flow.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://0-finance.bernama.com.pulse.petronas.com.my/news.php?id=1062702 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20141203080218/http://0-finance.bernama.com.pulse.petronas.com.my/news.php?id=1062702 |archivedate=3 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==The marketplace== Malaysia is strategically located at the heart of [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations|Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN)]], a region that pulses with a population of over 600 million,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asean.org/resources/publications/item/association-of-southeast-asian-nations-asean-integration-monitoring-report-a-joint-report-by-the-asean-secretariat-and-the-world-bank-english?category_id=382 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140816232045/http://www.asean.org/resources/publications/item/association-of-southeast-asian-nations-asean-integration-monitoring-report-a-joint-report-by-the-asean-secretariat-and-the-world-bank-english?category_id=382 |archivedate=16 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> total GDP of more than USD2 trillion,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aseanmarketresearch.com/services.html|title=Services - Asean Market Research|author=|date=|website=Aseanmarketresearch.com|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> total trade of USD2.5 trillion and with total FDI of USD108 billion. Being located in ASEAN, one of the world’s fastest growing regions,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/insights/public_sector/understanding_asean_seven_things_you_need_to_know|title=Understanding ASEAN: Seven things you need to know|author=|date=|website=McKinsey & Company|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> has attracted a thriving community of participants in the global Islamic finance industry. This has resulted in an integrated, end-to-end marketplace that has been recognised as a global destination for expertise, innovation and deal flow.
Malaysia is a fast-growing economy<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundaily.my/news/1033208|title=Malaysia’s economy to grow fastest among Asean-5|author=|date=|website=Thesundaily.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> whose liberal market policies are aimed at promoting trade, entrepreneurship, industrial and economic development.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.miti.gov.my/cms/index.jsp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216160419/http://www.miti.gov.my/cms/index.jsp |archivedate=16 December 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.matrade.gov.my/|title=Home - MATRADE|author=|date=|website=Matrade.gov.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mida.gov.my/home/|title=.: MIDA - Malaysian Investment Development Authority :. Perihal MIDA|author=|date=|website=Mida.gov.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> Initiatives undertaken by the [[Government of Malaysia|Malaysian Government]] and the private sector have always been investor-centric and business friendly with the aim of encouraging market development. This has transformed Malaysia into one of the most dynamic business environments in [[Southeast Asia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mida.gov.my/home/why-malaysia/posts/|title=.: MIDA - Malaysian Investment Development Authority :. Why Malaysia|author=|date=|website=Mida.gov.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! World Rank !! Report/Index !! |- | 20 || The Global Competitiveness Index 2014–2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GlobalCompetitivenessReport_2014-15.pdf|format=PDF|title=The Global Competitiveness Report 2014–2015|website=3.weforum.org|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> || Malaysia ranked 4th out of 144 economies for a well-developed and sound financial market. |- | 18 || World Bank’s Doing Business Report 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.doingbusiness.org/data/exploreeconomies/malaysia#getting-credit|title=Doing Business in Malaysia - World Bank Group|author=|date=|website=Doingbusiness.org|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> || Malaysia moved up 2 places in the annual World Bank’s Doing Business Report 2015 placing Malaysia as one of the best business destinations out of 189 economies around the world. |- |}
Characteristics of The marketplace # Robust regulatory, supervisory, Shariah and legal framework # Efficient and transparent price discovery platform # Deep primary market and active secondary trading of instruments # Diverse players and talent base with global capabilities and connectivity # Product breadth and depth, attractive to global investors and issuers # Efficient settlement system that allow settlement and clearing in RM, USD, and RMB
==Internationalising Sukuk Market== Malaysia remained the key issuer accounting for 69.3% or USD19.73bln of the total quarterly issuance. Cumulatively in 3Q14 YTD, Malaysia represents 64.9% of total issuances this year to date with more than USD61.4bln in new issuances volume, an increase of 6% in absolute volume compared to the USD58.2bln issued in the same period last year.
The Malaysian sukuk market has been tapped by a wide variety of issuers including benchmark sukuk of various maturities issued by the Malaysian central bank; capital raising and liquidity management sukuk issued by various Malaysian corporate institutions; infrastructure and fund-raising sukuk by the Malaysian government-related entities such as Pengurusan Air SPV Berhad; retail sukuk issued by Dana Infra giving Shariah-compliant capital market fixedincome investment opportunities to individuals;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/08/19/Danainfra-third-issuance-of-retail-Sukuk-oversubscribed/?style=biz|title=Danainfra third issuance of retail Sukuk oversubscribed - Business News - The Star Online|author=|date=|website=Thestar.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> and also by foreign issuers such as Bumitama Agri from Singapore that have issued sukuk in the Malaysian capital markets.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.maybank-ib.com/pdf/Press_Release_-_MKE_successfully_brings_Bumitama_to_the_Msian_Sukuk_market_with_its_maiden_MYR2b_Sukuk_programme.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521000524/http://www.maybank-ib.com/pdf/Press_Release_-_MKE_successfully_brings_Bumitama_to_the_Msian_Sukuk_market_with_its_maiden_MYR2b_Sukuk_programme.pdf |archivedate=21 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Sukuk were also issued denominated in foreign currencies including the world’s first Japanese Yen sukuk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/06/05/bankoftokyomitsubishi-sukuk-idUKL3N0OM20120140605|title=UPDATE 1-Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ sets up $500 mln sukuk...|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|date=|publisher=|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/09/25/BTMU-issues-worlds-first-yen-dominated-emas-sukuk/?style=biz|title=BTMU issues world's first Yen-dominated "Emas" sukuk - Business News - The Star Online|author=|date=|website=Thestar.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> Overall, a total of 114 sukuk tranches were domiciled in the Malaysian sukuk market in 3Q14.
The "Emas" designation is given to foreign-currency denominated sukuk issues. "[[Emas bond|Emas]]", which means gold in Bahasa Malaysia symbolized universal value and security.
==Growing Islamic Banking and Takaful Sectors== The Malaysian Islamic financial sector continues its growth trajectory, with robust growth in Islamic banking assets and takaful assets. The Islamic Banking sector in Malaysia has witnessed an increased market share on the back of growing demand for Islamic financial services.
Islamic banking has grown twice as fast in Malaysia as its conventional counterpart at a compounded annual growth rate of 22%, representing 24% to 25%% of total banking system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/03/12/Robust-Islamic-banking-Its-on-track-to-make-up-40-of-countrys-banking-sector-assets-by-2020/?style=biz|title=Islamic banking on track to make up 40% of Malaysia's banking sector assets - Business News - The Star Online|author=|date=|website=Thestar.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref>
The country is domicile to 11 takaful operators, two of which are foreign owned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnm.gov.my/index.php?ch=li&cat=insurance&type=TKF&fund=0&cu=0|title=List of Licensed Financial Institutions in Malaysia - Bank Negara Malaysia - Central Bank of Malaysia|author=|date=|website=Bnm.gov.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> The rate of growth in the takaful industry has been gaining traction to become one of the main segments of the country's insurance sector.
Retakaful operators in Malaysia add an extra layer of depth to the takaful industry through the spreading of risk and added capacity so that more risk can be underwritten.
==Vibrant and Innovative Islamic Equity Market== Malaysia’s Islamic finance marketplace has an efficient and transparent price discovery infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businesscircle.com.my/islamic-finance-malaysia-can-stay-ahead/|title=businesscircle.com.my|author=|date=|website=Businesscircle.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> Fund raising and investment activities in the Islamic capital market adhere to Islamic principles. Islamic equity market products in Malaysia include Shariah-compliant equities, Shariah-compliant collective investment schemes (unit trust funds, wholesale funds, I-REITs, I-ETFs), structured products, alternative funds(real estate, leasing, commodities) private equity funds and mixed asset (equity + fixed income + cash).
73% of total listed securities on Bursa Malaysia are Shariah-compliant.<ref name="sc.com.my">{{cite web|url=http://www.sc.com.my/post_archive/updated-list-of-shariah-compliant-securities-by-scs-shariah-advisory-council-12/|title=Updated List of Shariah-compliant Securities by SC's Shariah Advisory CouncilSecurities Commission Malaysia - Securities Commission Malaysia|author=|date=|website=Sc.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> The updated list of Shariah-compliant securities approved by its [[Shariah Advisory Council]] (SAC), which takes effect on 30 May 2014, features a total of 665 Shariah-compliant securities.<ref name="sc.com.my"/>
Malaysia had different asset classed to suit various investor needs. The industry in Malaysia grew from two Shariah-compliant unit trust funds in 1993 to more than 220 approved funds. Malaysia’s Islamic fund management industry with RM97.5bil in assets under management,<ref name="thestar.com.my">{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/Business/Business-News/2014/05/01/Msian-Islamic-capital-market-now-worth-RM15-trillion/?style=biz|title=Malaysian Islamic capital market now worth RM1.5 trillion - Business News - The Star Online|author=|date=|website=Thestar.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> is managed by 20 asset management companies<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sc.com.my/wp-content/uploads/eng/html/licensing/LoLI/LIFM.pdf|format=PDF|title=List of Capital Markets Services Licence holders for Islamic Fund Management as at 30 November 2014|website=Sc.com.my|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> licensed to exclusively manage shariah-compliant funds. Of the total assets under management, RM42bil is in the form of syariah-compliant unit trust funds which grew by 21% in 2013.<ref name="thestar.com.my"/>
==Talent Development - Sustaining the growth of Islamic Finance== The growth of Islamic finance in the past decade has been extraordinary. As the industry expands into untapped markets, there is a need to develop new talent that understands the industry and its underlying Shariah principles to support this growth. In response, Malaysia has undertaken initiatives to support the development of a highly skilled Islamic finance human capital workforce.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Institutions/Programme !! Description |- | [http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_talent&pg=pg_directory_talent_human&ac=107 IBFIM] || IBFIM is an industry-linked business entity dedicated to producing well-trained, high competence personnel and executives with the required talent in Islamic finance. |- | [http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_talent&pg=pg_directory_talent_human&ac=75 ICLIF] || ICLIF provides leadership development programmes for senior executives from financial institutions and business corporations. |- | [http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_talent&pg=pg_directory_talent_human&ac=76 INCEIF] || INCEIF is the world’s first fully dedicated Islamic finance university offering Master’s and PhD degrees and Chartered Islamic Finance Professional (CIFP) qualification. |- | [http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_talent&pg=pg_directory_talent_human&ac=77 ISRA] || ISRA is an international research house for applied Shariah research in Islamic finance and a repository of knowledge for Shariah views or Fatwas. |- | [http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_talent&pg=pg_directory_talent_human&ac=111 SIDC] || SIDC is a training and development provider on capital market, including the Islamic capital market such as Islamic Capital Market Graduate Training Scheme (ICMGTS), i-Advisor and Islamic Markets Programme (IMP) |- | FSTEP || FSTEP, managed by Institut Bank-Bank Malaysia (IBBM), offers an intensive 1-year training programme for entry level executives covering the four banking/insurance streams:Conventional banking, Investment banking, Islamic banking, and Insurance/Takaful. |}
==MIFC Executive Committee== The MIFC Executive Committee (MIFC EXCO), made up of senior industry and government figures, provides strategic direction to MIFC through policy review and role assignment powers. .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mifc.com/index.php?ch=ch_directory_regulators&pg=pg_directory_regulators_entities&ac=116|title=Malaysia International Islamic Financial Centre (MIFC)|author=|date=|website=Mifc.com|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref> The MIFC Promotions Unit serves as a liaison between investors, issuers, investment and Islamic banks, tertiary education institutions and the MIFC.
==MIFC communications campaigns== The MIFC Promotions Unit has implemented three communications campaigns since its launch in 2006. * The first, “Islamic finance meets in Malaysia” promoted Malaysia as a destination for companies and sovereigns looking to raise funds to meet with investors looking to put excess funds to work. * The second, “Shaping Islamic finance together” emphasised Malaysia’s role within the world as a collaborative partner in Islamic finance, showcasing Malaysia’s well developed regulatory framework and talent development institutions. * The third and current campaign “Malaysia: World’s Islamic Finance Marketplace” demonstrate the comprehensive and robust nature of Malaysia’s Islamic finance market. The marketplace is made up of the Islamic capital market, Islamic banking, Islamic money market, takaful and retakaful, Islamic fund management, talent development and professional ancillary services.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox person | name = Marc Ladreit de Lacharrière | image = Marc Ladreit de Lacharrière.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth-date and age|November 6, 1940}} | birth_place = [[Nice]], France | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = French | known_for = | education = | alma_mater = [[École nationale d'administration]] | occupation = Businessman | know_for = | networth = {{nowrap|[[United States dollar|US$]]310 million (''[[Forbes]]'' 2017)<ref name="Forbes 2016 The World's Billionaires" />}} | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | website = }}
'''Marc Eugène Charles Ladreit de Lacharrière''' (born November 6, 1940) is the [[CEO]] of [[FIMALAC]] (a.k.a. Financière Marc de Lacharrière), once majority owner of [[Fitch Group]] which now retains only 20% of it since the divestment to Hearst Corporation in March 2015.<ref name="forbes2007">[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2007/10/07billionaires_Marc-Ladreit-de-Lacharriere_6EPK.html Forbes 2007 profile]</ref><ref name="forbes2010">[https://www.forbes.com/lists/2010/10/billionaires-2010_Marc-Ladreit-de-Lacharriere_ZM6Q.html Forbes 2010 profile]</ref><ref name="hrw">[https://www.hrw.org/en/node/83293 Human Rights Watch biography]</ref><ref name="businessweek">[http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=863848&ticker=FIM:FP&previousCapId=291331&previousTitle=NISSAN%20MOTOR%20CO%20LTD BusinessWeek profile]</ref><ref name="lexpress">Lacharrière : «Finance et culture sont complémentaires», in ''[[L'Express]]'', 05/10/2007 [http://www.lexpress.fr/actualite/economie/laquo-finance-et-culture-sont-compl-eacute-mentaires-raquo_476156.html]</ref><ref name="unesco">[https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=31862&Cr=unesco&Cr1= UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador nomination]</ref>
On the ''[[Forbes]]'' 2016 list of the world's billionaires, he was ranked #722 with a net worth of [[United States dollar|US$]]2.4 billion.<ref name="Forbes 2016 The World's Billionaires">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/marc-ladreit-de-lacharriere/?list=billionaires |title=The World's Billionaires (2016 ranking): #722 Marc Ladreit de Lacharriere |date=March 1, 2016 |work=[[Forbes]] | accessdate=2017-01-01}}</ref>
==Early life== Marc Ladreit de Lacharrière was born on November 6, 1940 in [[Nice]].<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="lexpress" /><ref name="beauxarts">[http://www.academie-des-beaux-arts.fr/membres/actuel/libres/Lacharriere/fiche.htm Académie des Beaux Arts biography]</ref> From 1968 to 1970, he attended the [[École nationale d'administration]].<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="lexpress" /><ref name="renault" /><ref name="casino">[http://www.groupe-casino.fr/fr/Marc-Ladreit-de-Lacharriere.html Groupe Casino biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110802042825/http://www.groupe-casino.fr/fr/Marc-Ladreit-de-Lacharriere.html |date=2011-08-02 }}</ref>
==Career== In 1961, he started a teen [[magazine]] and sold it off a few years later.<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /> He then worked for [[Suez (company)|Suez]], [[Masson (publisher)|Masson]], and ''[[Valeurs Actuelles]]''.<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="lexpress" /> He worked for [[L'Oréal]] for fifteen years, and was its CEO for a while.<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="hrw" /> He served as the Chairman of [[Duff & Phelps]].<ref name="businessweek" /> He is a member of the Board of Directors of [[Renault]], L'Oréal, [[Groupe Casino]], [[Gilbert Coullier Productions]], [[Cassina S.p.A.|Cassina]], and [[Canal Plus]].<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="businessweek" /><ref name="renault">[http://www.renault.com/en/groupe/management-et-gouvernance/conseil-d-administration/pages/marc-ladreit-de-lacharri%C3%A8re.aspx Renault board]</ref><ref name="casino" /> He is Honorary Chairman of the [[Comité national des conseillers du commerce extérieur de la France]] (French National Committee of Foreign Trade Advisors), and a member of the Consultative Committee of [[Banque de France]].<ref name="renault" /> He is a former member of the Steering Committee of the [[Bilderberg Group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bilderbergmeetings.org/former-steering-committee-members.html |title=Former Steering Committee Members |work=bilderbergmeetings.org |publisher=[[Bilderberg Group]] |accessdate=2014-02-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202095633/http://www.bilderbergmeetings.org/former-steering-committee-members.html |archivedate=2014-02-02 |df= }}</ref>
==Philanthropy== He sits on the Board of the American Friends of the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]].<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="hrw" /><ref name="lexpress" /> He helped renovate the [[Théâtre du Rond-Point]] in [[Paris]].<ref name="forbes2007" /><ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="lexpress" /> He is a former Vice-Chairman of [[Fondation Agir Contre l'Exclusion]] (FACE), which he co-founded with [[Martine Aubry]].<ref name="businessweek" /><ref name="lexpress" /> He is also a member of the [[Fondation Culture et Diversité]], [[Conseil artistique des musées nationaux]], [[Fondation Bettencourt Schueller]], [[Fondation nationale des sciences politiques]], [[Musée des Arts Décoratifs, Paris|Musée des arts décoratifs]], the Société des Amis du [[Musée du quai Branly]].<ref name="businessweek" /><ref name="lexpress" /><ref name="renault" /><ref>[http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=46412&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html UNESCO picture] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202065803/http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID%3D46412%26URL_DO%3DDO_TOPIC%26URL_SECTION%3D201.html |date=2012-02-02 }}</ref> In 2006, he was elected to the [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]].<ref name="hrw" /><ref name="beauxarts" /> In August 2010, he was named [[Goodwill Ambassador]] for the [[UNESCO]].<ref name="forbes2010" /><ref name="unesco" /> He is the President of the ''[[Revue des deux Mondes]]''.<ref name="hrw" />
==Personal life== He is divorced, with four children.<ref name="forbes2007" />
==Filmography== * 2017 : [[Patients]] (co-producer)
==See also== * [[List of French people by net worth]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ladreit, Marc}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Nice]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:French billionaires]] [[Category:French philanthropists]] [[Category:Members of the Steering Committee of the Bilderberg Group]] [[Category:UNESCO Goodwill Ambassadors]]

'''Market access''' for goods means the conditions, [[tariff]] and [[Non-tariff barriers to trade|Non-tariff measures (NTMs)]], set by countries for the entry of specific goods into their markets. In the [[World Trade Organization|WTO]], tariff commitments for goods are agreed upon and set out in each member's [[schedules of concessions]] on goods. The schedules represent commitments not to apply tariffs above the listed rates — these rates are “bound”. Under WTO rules, bound rates may not be raised without compensating the affected members.
Non-tariff measures (NTMs) are non-tariff policy measures that affect international trade. NTMs cover a broad range of measures both directly and indirectly related to trade, and their use has risen as tariff rates have fallen under subsequent WTO negotiation rounds. In many cases, NTMs can be classified as [[non-tariff barriers to trade|non-tariff barriers to trade (NTBs)]]. Some areas of NTMs are dealt with under specific WTO agreements, notably the [[Agreement on the Application of Sanitary and Phytosanitary Measures]], the [[Agreement on Technical Barriers to Trade]], the Anti-dumping agreement, the Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures and the Agreement on Safeguards. WTO Members seek to continually improve market access through the regular WTO work programme and through negotiations such as those launched at the [[Doha Ministerial Conference]] in November 2001.
==Market access and import regulations== Countries have various different systems controlling the import of products. Often authorization from certification bodies and/or international [[product certification]] is required. An overview of market access regulations can be given for example by http://fita.org/countries/ or http://www.macmap.org/.
==Pharmacoeconomics== Market Access is also used in [[Pharmacoeconomics]] and refers to the process by which a company gets a drug to market so that it becomes available for patients. Access is defined as a patient's ability to obtain medical care. Ease of access is determined by such factors as the availability of medical services and their acceptability to the patient, location of health care facilities, the transportation, the hours of operation and cost of care.<sup>1</sup> Evidence-Based Market Access (see [[Evidence-based medicine]]) refers to a process for producing Market Access reports based on scientific, preferably [[peer-reviewed]] and referenced material.
==References== * Pashos C, Klein E, Wanke L, (ed.). ISPOR Lexicon. 1st ed. Princeton, NJ: International Society for Pharmacoeconomics and Outcomes Research;1998.
==Useful Databases on Market Access== * ITC's [http://www.macmap.org/'''Market Access Map'''], interactive portal providing information on customs tariffs and market requirements. * ITC's [http://ntmsurvey.intracen.org/home '''Non-Tariff Measures Business Survey'''] database, including regulatory and procedural obstacles that trading companies face both at home and abroad.
[[Category:International trade]]
{{international-trade-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Dr. Mohammed Sharaf | image = Mohammed Sharaf DP World (6829741040) (cropped).jpg | caption = Sharaf in March 2012 | birth_name = | birth_date = 1961 | birth_place = [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = Emirati | education = Business Administration and Management at [[University of Arizona]] | occupation =*[[Chief executive officer|Group CEO]] of [[DP World]] *[[Chairman#Vice chairman and deputy chairman|Joint Vice Chairman]] of [[U.S.-U.A.E. Business Council]] | known_for = | boards =*Member of UAE-Canada Business Council Board *Member of DP world's Nominations and Governance Committee | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }}
'''Mohammed Sharaf''', is a [[Emiratis|Emirati]] businessman, who was the [[Chief executive officer|Group CEO]] of [[DP World|Dubai Ports World]], one of the biggest [[Port operator|ports operator]] in the world. He was the Group CEO of DP World till December 2015 when he announced his sudden retirement from the company.
==Career== Sharaf started his shipping career, at [[Howland Hook Marine Terminal|Howland Hook terminal]] in the [[Port of New York and New Jersey]]. He joined Dubai Ports Authority in 1992, and in 2001 he became Managing Director of DP World UAE Region. During his mandate, Sharaf performed central roles in developing the terminals of [[Jeddah Seaport|Jeddah]], [[Port of Constanța|Constanta]], [[Visakhapatnam Port|Vizag]], [[Port of Jebel Ali|Jebel Ali]] and [[Port Rashid]]. Actually Mohammed Sharaf is the [[DP World]]'s Group CEO since 2005 and the DP world's company Director since 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.dpworld.com/about-dp-world/board-of-directors/|title=DP World Marine Ports and Terminals {{!}} Board of Directors|website=web.dpworld.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> Mohammed Sharaf received his degree in Business Administration from the [[University of Arizona]] <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://global.arizona.edu/global-knowledge-network/distinguished-alumni|title=Distinguished Alumni {{!}} UA Global Initiatives|website=global.arizona.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref> Mohammed Sharaf retired from DP World on January 26, 2016. Mohammed Sharaf was appointed Assistant Foreign Minister of Economic & Trade Affairs of the UAE on July 17, 2017.
==Management philosophy== Sharaf experienced the [[Work ethic|tough work]] associated with wharf life when he was a 'Manager Trainee' at the now-defunct [[United States Lines|U.S. Lines]]. This experience shaped his 'management philosophy' and he expressed it in an interview: ''I believe that someone at the top must know the bottom, otherwise you are going to be just playing with the numbers and not knowing the reality of the business''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323894704578108493326703184|title=DP World Is Riding Out the Global Storm|last=Hatoum|first=Leila|date=2012-11-12|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-05-29|last2=Falconer|first2=Tim|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
==Supply chain optimization==
According to Sharaf, [[automation]] and [[Emerging technologies|new technologies]] are the way of the future, as they are the means to [[Supply chain optimization|optimize the wider supply chain]], generated by the new mega-ships, on land.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/article/20140129/ARTICLE/301299836/1037|title=DP World pioneers world’s largest semi-automated facility|last=Report|first=Staff|website=www.khaleejtimes.com|access-date=2018-05-29}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Mugo Kibati |image = Kibati.png |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1969}} |residence = [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] |nationality = Kenyan |alma_mater ='''[[Moi University]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Technology]] in [[Electrical Engineering]])}}
'''[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]'''
{{small|([[Master of Science]] in Technology and Policy)}}
'''[[George Washington University School of Business]]'''
{{small|([[Master of Business Administration]])}}
'''[[St Peter's College, Oxford]]'''
{{small|([[Economics|Certificate in European Union Economics]])}} | title = ''Current Roles'' Chief Executive Officer, [[Telkom Kenya]]
Chairman, [[M-kopa]] Solar
Chairman, [[Lake Turkana Wind Power Station]]
''Previous Roles'' Director General [[Kenya Vision 2030]]
Chief Executive Officer, East African Cables Limited
Technical Marketing Manager, [[Lucent Technologies]] |website = {{URL|mugokibati.com}} | boards = |networth = |spouse = |children = }} '''Mugo Kibati''' is a [[Kenya]]n [[electrical engineer]], [[businessman]] and [[corporate executive]], who, since 9 November 2018, serves as the [[chief executive officer]] of [[Telkom Kenya]], the third-largest telecommunications company in the country.{{cite web|access-date=9 November 2018 | url=https://www.nation.co.ke/business/Telkom-appoints-Mugo-Kibati-as-CEO/996-4844466-84sod1/ |title=Telkom appoints Mugo Kibati as CEO |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |first=Bonface | last=Otieno |location=Nairobi}} He is the former Group CEO of [[Sanlam Kenya plc|Sanlam Kenya]], where he led a team overseeing the expansion of the business from life to general insurance, investments and asset management. During his tenure, the company re-branded from the PanAfrica brand to Sanlam.{{cite web|date=19 August 2016 | url=https://africabusinesscommunities.com/news/kenya-pan-african-insurance-rebrands-to-sanlam-kenya-as-it-seeks-targets-more-market-share.html |title=Pan African insurance rebrands to Sanlam Kenya as it seeks targets more market share |access-date=9 November 2018 |publisher=Africa Business Communities |first=Bob | last=Koigi |location=Haarlem, Netherlands}} ==Background and education== Kibati graduated from [[Moi University]] in 1991, with a [[Bachelor of Technology]] ([[Electrical Engineering]]) degree. He holds a [[Master of Science]] degree in Technology and Policy, from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT).{{cite web|access-date=9 November 2018 |date=9 November 2018 |url=https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2018/11/telkom-kenya-appoints-mugo-kibati-its-new-ceo/ |title=Telkom Kenya appoints Mugo Kibati its new CEO |publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM]] |author=Capital FM Correspondent | location=Nairobi}} The Technology and Policy Program (TPP) at MIT "addresses societal challenges ... at the intersection of technology and policy, mobilizing science and engineering to inform intelligent, responsible strategies and policies to benefit communities from local to global." Kibati's other credentials include a [[Master of Business Administration]] degree from [[George Washington University School of Business]]. He also holds a [[Economics|Certificate in European Union Economics]] from [[St Peter's College, Oxford|Oxford University, St. Peters College,]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. ==Career== Mugo Kibati is the Chairman of [[Lake Turkana Wind Power Station|Lake Turkana Wind Power Limited]]. Completed in January 2017, the 40,000-acre, 310MW wind farm is the largest inward investment into Kenya since its independence, and the largest renewable energy transaction in Africa’s history to date.{{cite web|access-date=9 November 2018 | url=https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2018/10/lake-turkana-wind-power-project-to-connect-365-turbines-to-the-grid/ | title=Lake Turkana Wind Power project to connect 365 turbines to the grid |date=22 October 2018 |publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM]] | author=Capital FM Reporter |location=Nairobi}} In February 2016, Kibati was appointed the Chairman of [[M-kopa|M-Kopa]] Solar, a role he retains to date. The company has connected over 600,000 homes to affordable solar power, with 500 new homes being added everyday, as of January, 2018.{{cite web|title=M-Kopa hires Mugo Kibati as board chair |url=https://www.nation.co.ke/business/corporates/Mugo-Kibati-hired-as-M-Kopa-board-chairman/1954162-3119470-r23jqv/index.html |newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |date=16 March 2016 |access-date=9 November 2018 |first=Otiato |last=Guguyu | location=Nairobi}} In February 2015, Kibati joined Sanlam Kenya (then PanAfrica Insurance), an insurance and investment company and a member of the South-African [[Sanlam]] Group, as CEO.{{cite web|url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/news/Sanlam-Kenya-CEO-Mugo-Kibati-resigns/539546-4289810-lmxb9p/index.html | title=Sanlam Kenya CEO Mugo Kibati set to leave at end month | newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |date=3 February 2018 | access-date=9 November 2018 |first=Victor |last=Juma | location=Nairobi}}{{cite web| url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/Mugo-Kibati-appointed-new-CEO-of-Pan-Africa-Insurance-/539550-2635532-3ufx53/index.html |title=Mugo Kibati appointed new CEO of Pan Africa Insurance |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] | date=25 February 2018 |access-date=9 November 2018 |last=Juma | first=Victor |location=Nairobi}} In July 2009, Kibati was appointed Director General of [[Kenya Vision 2030]]. In that role, Kibati spearheaded the implementation of [[Kenya Vision 2030]], the official national strategy to transform Kenya into a newly industrialized country by the year 2030. During his tenure, Kibati, with the support of his colleagues in government, the private sector and civil society, laid the foundation for structured national transformation. He is also credited with rallying diverse stakeholders toward consensus on the pathway to economic growth and social development. He exited the role in October 2013.{{cite web|title=Mugo Kibati confirms exit from Vision 2030 Secretariat |access-date=9 November 2018 |date=15 October 2013 |url=https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2013/10/mugo-kibati-confirms-exit-from-vision-2030-secretariat/ | author=Capital FM Reporter |publisher=[[98.4 Capital FM]] | location=Nairobi}} Kibati served as CEO and Group Managing Director of the East African Cables for four years until June 2008. During this time, the company implemented a successful diversification and growth strategy, increasing annual revenues from KSh. 400 million to Ksh. 3.5 billion, profits from KSh. 15 million to Ksh. 600 million and market share value of the company from KSh. 600 million to KSh12 billion. The strategy included negotiated strategic partnership with a leading global cable manufacturer and acquisition of manufacturing facilities in Tanzania and South Africa. By the end of his tenure, the company has achieved 'blue chip' status as well as the fastest-growing share price on the Nairobi Stock Exchange (2005/6) while exceeding statutory transparency obligations.{{cite web|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |date=16 July 2015 |url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/East-African-Cables-CEO-resigns-after-7-years-at-the-helm/539550-2791992-nvwfb0z/index.html |title=East African Cables CEO resigns after 7 years at the helm |access-date=9 November 2018 |first=Victor | last=Juma |location=Nairobi}} As an engineer, Kibati worked at [[Lucent|Lucent Technologies]], in the United States as a Technical Marketing Manager. He also worked at the [[Bamburi Cement]] Company Limited (Lafarge Copee) from November 1991 to May 1997 following an early stint at the Kenya Petroleum Refineries in Mombasa, Kenya. ==Other considerations== Kibati has served on several corporate boards, including I&M Bank and the Apollo Group. He has also held top national industry leadership positions at the Federation of Kenya Employers, the Kenya Association of Manufacturers and the Kenya Private Sector Alliance. He also served on the Board of Governors and chaired the Old Boys' Association of the Alliance High School for several years. == Awards == *Fellow of the [[Young African Leaders Initiative]] (2012) *Young Global Leader by the [[World Economic Forum]] (2008) *Member of the [[Aspen Institute]] Global Leadership Network. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.mugokibati.com Personal website of Mugo Kibati] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=99612383&privcapId=23250349 Executive Profile of Mugo Kibati at Bloomberg.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kibati, Mugo}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1969 births]] [[Category:Kenyan engineers]] [[Category:Kenyan electrical engineers]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:George Washington University School of Business alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Moi University alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of St Peter's College, Oxford]] [[Category:Kenyan chief executives]]

{{Multiple issues| {{orphan|date=August 2010}} {{BLP sources|date=August 2010}} {{advert|date=August 2010}} }} {{Infobox governor |name= Neal Asbury |image=NealAsbury.jpg |birth_date= {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|02|05}} |birth_place= [[Columbus, Ohio]] |residence= [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] |spouse= [[Elizabeth Trixia Gomez Carpio]] |alma_mater= [[Rowan University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]) |profession= [[President, The Legacy Companies]]
[[Talk Show Host]]
[[Author]] |signature= }} '''Neal Asbury''' (born May 2, 1957) is an [[United States|American]] [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]] and Chief Executive of The Legacy Companies. In addition to being an [[advocate]] of [[entrepreneurship]] and [[free enterprise]], he is a [[published]] [[author]], and he hosts the nationally syndicated talk radio show ''Neal Asbury's Truth for America'' (''now Neal Asbury's Made in America''). ==Early life== Neal Asbury attended [[Jefferson Township High School (New Jersey)|Jefferson Township High School]] in [[Jefferson Township, New Jersey]]. After graduation he enrolled in Rowan University in [[New Jersey]]. Neal graduated from [[Rowan University]] in 1979 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Music.{{cite web|title=Fox News "Interview" on Federal Funding for Video Games|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=e80_1305997846|work = [[Fox News]] | accessdate = 2011-06-06 | date = 2011-05-21}} == Career == After graduating from [[Rowan State University]] Neal began working in the mail room of a [[Fifth Avenue]] as a food service exporter. A year later, Asbury moved on to Manila, working as a director of sales for a large trading company and traveling to capitals throughout the Far East. Seven years later, he founded [[Asbury Worldwide]].{{Cite web | last = Neyman | first = Julie | title = Business is cooking for one local food service equipment exporter - South Florida Business Journal | work = South Florida Business Journal | accessdate = 2010-08-02 | date = 2008-05-02 | url = http://southflorida.bizjournals.com/southflorida/stories/2008/05/05/story11.html }} In 1987, Asbury Worldwide grew to include twelve distribution facilities around the globe. In 1989, Neal began FAB Asia, Inc. in [[Manila]], Philippines which was the Asian fabricator of commercial kitchens for McDonald's as well as other [[United States|American]] restaurant chains. After selling his group of companies in July 1999, Mr. Asbury established [[Greenfield World Trade]] which is a global trading company selling and servicing American manufactured products in over 130 countries to both the retail and commercial markets. He acquired J. Cobo (a distribution company with operations throughout Latin America), General (a manufacturer of food preparation equipment), Zeroll (a manufacturer of kitchen gadgets), and Omega (a manufacturer of electrical kitchen appliances). ==Awards and Distinctions== Asbury has received the E-Star Export Award and the Export Achievement Award from the [[U.S]]. [[Department of Commerce]]. Asbury's company was recognized as National Champion Exporter of The Year(2008) after they were first recognized in February as Exporter of the Year for Florida, which was preceded by being selected as the Region IV Exporter of the Year, covering the [[Southeast United States]]. Greenfield World Trade's Neal Asbury Named SBA's National Champion Exporter of the Year.{{Cite web | last = Brimm | first = David | title = Greenfield World Trade's Neal Asbury Named SBA's National Champion Exporter of the... |work = Reuters | accessdate = 2010-08-02 | date = 2008-04-23 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/idUS140587+23-Apr-2008+BW20080423 }} He was also a finalist for the [[Ernst & Young]] Entrepreneur of the Year Award in 2010. He is a founding faculty member of Export University (a collaboration between the District Export Council and the [[U.S. Department of Commerce]]). He is also the chairman of the Export University National Oversight Committee. Additionally, he is a vice chairman of the District Export Council National Steering Committee and a chairman of the [[Florida]] District Export Council, appointed to serve by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce. Asbury also serves as a member of the International Advisory Committee to Governor [[Charlie Crist]] of Florida and he is a member of the International Policy Committee of the [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]] in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] D.C. He has testified before the [[Philippine Senate]] on multiple occasions on foreign trade. ==Radio Show and Blog== Each week Asbury hosts a nationally broadcast talk radio show, ''Neal Asbury's Made In America'', (formerly ''Truth For America''), produced by Atlantic Radio Network. It is broadcast around the country by [[Radio America (United States)|Radio America]] and deals with topics related to America’s [[entrepreneurial spirit]] and the American Dream. Asbury also writes the Conscientious Equity blog, which focuses on his interest for small business, entrepreneurship and the benefits of expanding the U.S. role in global commerce. Topics discussed on the Conscientious Equity blog range from the health care crisis to job creation and international trade. Asbury’s blog entries are often syndicated online, appearing on such sites as Moneynews.com.{{cite web|last=Asbury|first=Neal|title=Neal Asbury|url=http://www.moneynews.com/Insiders/NealAsbury/bio-119|publisher=Moneynews.com|accessdate=21 January 2014}} His advocacy has taken him to address the [[United Nations]] at the Commission of Trade and Development, as well as frequent speaking engagements at universities, government events and trade associations. ==Personal Life== On December 29 in 1984 Neal married Elizabeth Trixia Gomez Carpio, an actress from the Philippines. They have two daughters, Alyssa Kyla Asbury and Anjelica Dawn Asbury. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Asbury, Neal}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Columbus, Ohio]] [[Category:American businesspeople]]
